title: Managing Type 2 on Vacation

content: Far from my refrigerator, regular meal schedule, and gym classes, my attention to diet and exercise can often fly through the hotel window.
It’s not that I forget my Type 2 diabetes, but without those safeguards, I invariably pack on a few pounds and register a few blood sugar readings that are, let us say, less than ideal.

But presented the choice between a double scoop of butter pecan ice cream so dairy fresh that I can literally hear the cows mooing in their pens as I dig in or sitting in an overheated car while everyone else rushes to get in line, what’s a girl to do?

All of this comes courtesy of my recent vacay in Lewes, DE, where I counted dolphin fins while visiting Cape Henlopen, floated in perfectly still blue-green water, and ate enough varieties of eggplant (I’m a vegetarian) to sink a ship.

And it wasn’t as though I didn’t try to stay in decent control. But the eggplant came fried, battered, stewed in oil, wrapped around fresh mozzarella, etc., rather than my careful preparations that cut the fat and carbs. (They were all perfectly delicious.)

content: And it wasn’t that I didn’t get any exercise. There were lazy walks along the beach, a few slow bike rides to see the sites, and running up and down the steps to our hotel room. Not to mention walking through a tour of a beer distillery. But – and I’m trying to be honest here – excellent slices of warm Italian bread to go with that fabulously greasy eggplant and a few saltwater taffies to prove we really were at the beach trumped my less-than-normal activity.

First, if it’s only for a few days, or even a week, I resolve not to worry. Worry means stress and stress can boost your sugars. But if you want to keep things moderately in check during time away, here’s a few tips to keep things from spiraling out of control.

First, if it’s only for a few days, or even a week, I resolve not to worry. Worry means stress and stress can boost your sugars. But if you want to keep things moderately in check during time away, here’s a few tips to keep things from spiraling out of control.

sections.heading: Take your meds and log your sugars.
content: These are non-negotiables. It’s easy to eat a bag of caramel kettle corn, but don’t forget to log your sugars 2 hours later. If they spiral, resolve to get some kind of exercise – if only a 20-minute walk. Give yourself the gift of lots of water and a more restrained eating day on the morrow.

sections.heading: Treat yourself, but not too much.
content: My two scoops of butter pecan were kid-sized. Yes, they did drive up my sugars, but I made sure to eat them at 2 p.m., so I’d have time to work them down (somewhat) before bed. And, though I dearly wanted it, I didn’t have chocolate or marshmallow sauce!

Fill up on salad. As a self-described vegetable junkie, when I’m out of town, I try to add a small salad to every meal – breakfast, lunch and dinner. That way, I can have the eggplant rollatini with that fabulous handmade mozzarella, but I might only finish half a serving.
Consider splitting a meal. If you’re with friends or a partner consider dividing an entrée or only ordering two appetizers for your dinner. That way, a clean plate might mean a reduced calorie load.
Vacations should be fun and relaxing. Don’t let Type 2 get in the way. By keeping tabs on your exercise, diet and meds, an occasional treat shouldn’t get in the way of overall good care. Bon voyage!
